choices.text: Omit the morning dose of both insulin and glimepiride and continue antihypertensives
Omit all medications on the day of surgery
Continue all medications on the day of surgery
Omit insulin, glimepiride and telmisartan and continue amlodipine on the day of surgery

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient who is a known case of diabetes and hypertension is posted for an elective laparoscopic hernioplasty and takes regular insulin and oral glimepiride for his diabetes and tablet telmisartan and amlodipine for his hypertension. What would be the pre-operative advice you will give to this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Pain at the intravenous site is LEAST with which IV drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    Pain with the intravenous injection is common with diazepam, etomidate, methohexital, and propofol.

•    It is very rare after thiopental and ketamine 

•    Maximum pain on injection is seen with etomidate.

questions.text: All the following are ester type of local anesthetic except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    Local anesthetic molecules comprise of aromatic benzene ring and a tertiary amine.

•    Both of these are joined by an intermediate chain.

•    Based on the chemical structure of this intermediate chain, local anesthetics are divided into 2 types:

1: Ester local anesthetics: eg procaine, benzocaine, tetracaine, chloroprocaine 

2: Amide local anesthetics: eg lignocaine, bupivacaine, prilocaine, ropivacaine

questions.text: After a failed attempt at direct laryngoscopy for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the anesthesiologist decided to insert a supraglottic airway device to keep oxygenating the patient. According to difficult airway association (DAS) guidelines which plan is this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

choices.text: Augments the CO2 responsiveness of the cerebral vasculature

questions.text: Ketamine
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    Ketamine is thought to increase CBF and, consequently, CBV and ICP, by two mechanisms: there may be a direct effect on cerebral vascular smooth muscle to cause vasodilation

•    there may be a “coupled” effect caused by an increase in CMR.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is posted for laparoscopic hernia surgery and is induced with propofol and scoline for intubation. After securing the airway, the patient is given atracurium for muscle relaxation and morphine for analgesia. Soon after that following capnograph was observed. What is your interpretation of the clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•    The drugs used in the questions gives us a clue to diagnosis.

•    Both atracurium and morphine release histamine and so can cause bronchospasm

•    Bronchospasm is an obstructive lung condition and there is difficulty in expiration causing steep upstroke on capnography whose shape can be described a “ shark fin appearance”

questions.text: Which of the following types of regional anesthesia is associated with the GREATEST serum concentration of lidocaine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    The site of injection of the local anesthetic is one of the most important factors influencing systemic local anesthetic absorption and toxicity. 

•    The degree of absorption from the site of injection depends on the blood supply to that site. 

•    Areas that have the greatest blood supply have the greatest systemic absorption. 

•    For this reason, the greatest plasma concentration of local anesthetic occurs after an intercostal block.

•    Overall, the order of absorption can be described as:

•    Decreasing order of absorption from the site of administration:

► B: BLOOD (INTRAVASCULAR)> BRONCHIAL (INTRA TRACHEAL) >

► I: INTERCOSTAL NERVE BLOCK> INTRA PLURAL NERVE BLOCK >

► C: CAUDAL EPIDURAL> PARACERVICAL NERVE BLOCK>

► E: EPIDURAL LUMBAR >

► P: PLEXUS BRACHIAL >

► S: SCIATIC NERVE BLOCK > SUB CUTANEOUS

choices.text: MRI compatible anesthesia gas cylinder are made of molybdenum steel
Pin index system prevents wrong attachment of anesthesia cylinder to machine
Pin index of Nitrous oxide cylinder is 1,5
Oxygen flush is a part of high-pressure system

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Option A: 

► Mri compatible anesthesia gas cylinders are made up of aluminium as they are non-ferromagnetic substance

► Normal cylinders that are used elsewhere are made up of an alloy called as molybdenum steel which is light weight.

Option B: 

► Pin index safety system (PISS) prevent wrong attachment of anesthesia cylinder to anesthesia machine

► Diameter Index Safety System (DISS) prevents wrong attachment of gas pipeline to machine.

Option C: 

► There is a set of 2 holes which are placed with respect to a central hole in Pin Index Safety System and these locations are gas specific.

► These are as follows

•    Air: 1,5

•    Oxygen: 2,5

•    Nitrous oxide: 3,5

•    CO2 (>7.5%): 1,6

•    CO2 (<7.5%): 2,6

•    Cyclopropane: 3,6

•    Entonox: 7

Option D: 

► Oxygen flush is a part of intermediate pressure system.

choices.text: His bag and mask ventilation will be easy, but it will be a difficult intubation
His intubation and bag and mask ventilation will be both easy
His intubation will be easy but difficult to comment on bag and mask ventilation
His intubation and bag and mask ventilation will be both difficult

questions.text:
A patient comes to pre anesthesia OPD and on airway examination of his oral cavity the anesthesiologist was able to see the hard palate, the soft palate, and the base of uvula was visible along with the tongue. Also, the patient was edentulous and was obese with a BMI of 35 kg\m2.

What would be his interpretation of above findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    Mallampati proposed a classification system (Mallampati score) to correlate the oropharyngeal space with the ease of direct laryngoscopy and tracheal intubation.

•    With the observer at eye level, the patient holds the head in a neutral position, opens the mouth maximally, and protrudes the tongue without phonating. 

•    The airway is classified according to the visible structures 

Class I: The soft palate, fauces, uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible.

Class II: The soft palate, fauces, and uvula ( except tip )are visible.

Class III: The soft palate and base of the uvula are visible.

Class IV: The soft palate is not visible.

Class I and II are considered to be easy intubations

Class III and IV are difficult intubations

Predictors of difficult Bag and Mask ventilation are:

O: Obese ( BMI>30 kg\m2)

B: Bearded individual

E: Edentulous ( no teeth )

S: History of Snoring ( obstructive sleep apnea)

E: Elderly ( age>55 years)

•    In this scenario both predictors of difficult intubation and mask ventilation are evident so both can be expected to be difficult.

choices.text: Extubation in light planes of anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for laryngospasm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    Laryngospasm is the sustained closure of the vocal cords resulting in the partial or complete loss of the patient's airway.

•    It is a primitive protective airway reflex that exists to protect against aspiration but can occur in light planes of anaesthesia.

•    Laryngospasm can rapidly result in hypoxaemia and bradycardia.

•    Common anaesthetic factors include 

1.    Light anaesthesia at the time of stimulus usually at extubation

2.    The use of a potentially more irritant volatile anaesthetic such as isoflurane or desflurane 

3.    The presence of blood or secretions in the airway

4.    Instrumentation of the airway at light planes of anaesthesia. 

5.    Young children with hypersensitivity of the airway (from infective, inflammatory, or other irritation such as passive smoking) have a 10-fold increase in the risk of laryngospasm. 

Tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy have been associated with a >20% incidence of laryngospasm.

questions.text: Each of the following will cause erroneous readings by dual-wavelength pulse oximeters EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    The presence of haemoglobin species other than oxyhaemoglobin can cause erroneous readings by dual wavelength pulse oximeters. 

•    Haemoglobin species such as carboxyhaemoglobin and methaemoglobin, dyes such as methylene blue and indocyanine green, and some colours of nail polish will cause erroneous readings.

•    Because the absorption spectrum of fetal haemoglobin is like that of adult oxyhaemoglobin, fetal haemoglobin does not significantly affect the accuracy of these types of pulse oximeters. 

•    High levels of bilirubin have no significant effect on the accuracy of dual-wavelength pulse oximeters

questions.text: Which state of local anesthetic molecule is required for the onset of action
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    Local anesthetics are Na+ channel blockers.

•    The site of action is the intracellular surface of the channel.

•    For the drug to reach its site of action it needs to be in unionized form i.e lipophilic form to cross the cell membrane.

•    But the active form of LA is its ionized form and it is present around receptor intracellularly

questions.text: Which of the following is an effect of use of etomidate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    Etomidate causes dose dependant inhibition of 11 beta hydroxylase enzyme which is involved in cortisol synthesis and so causes adrenocortical suppression.

•    Therefore, long term infusion of etomidate in ICU for sedation is to be avoided.

choices.text: Initially increase in MAC followed by later decrease in MAC

questions.text: Pregnancy has
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    Pregnancy lowers MAC

•    This may be related to the sedative effects of progesterone.  

•    Pregnant patients also are very sensitive to local anesthetics

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common route of loss of heat during surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•    The order of loss of heat from the patient during surgery and anesthesia is

•    Radiation > convection > conduction > evaporation

questions.text: Most common agent used to expediate the recovery from the action of non-depolarising muscle relaxants is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    NDMRs are competitive inhibitors at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

•    The action of NDMRs is terminated by their metabolism and thus decrease in their concentration at the receptor

•    This termination of action can be expediated by administration of a cholinesterase inhibitor that will increase the acetylcholine concentration at the receptor, and this increase the speed of reversal of muscle relaxation.

•    Many cholinesterase inhibitors can be used of which neostigmine is the most used drug

•    Others are physostigmine and edrophonium.

•    These drugs are non-specific and so they increase the acetylcholine at both nicotinic as well as muscarinic receptors and cause lot of muscarinic side effects.

•    To avoid them, these drugs are always co-administered with an anticholinergic e.g., glycopyrrolate or atropine

questions.text: The most common side effect of dantrolene therapy is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•    Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant used acutely in the prevention and treatment of malignant hyperthermia in patients undergoing anesthesia. 

•    Dantrolene has little or no effect on smooth or cardiac muscle at clinical doses. 

•    Dantrolene works directly on skeletal muscle by decreasing the amount of calcium released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

•    This decreases the excitation–contraction coupling needed for the muscle to contract. 

•    The most common side effect of dantrolene administration is skeletal muscle weakness. 

•    Other acute side effects include nausea, diarrhoea, and blurred vision. 

•    When the drug is given intravenously, a brisk diuresis occurs and is related to the mannitol added to make the 
intravenous solution isotonic

questions.text: Most common cause of intraoperative anaphylaxis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    The most common Etiology of intraop anaphylaxis is

•    Antibiotics > muscle relaxants > chlorhexidine

choices.text: To facilitate faster induction with inhaled anesthetic agents
To relieve anxiety associated with the surgery
Decreasing the dose of anesthetic drugs

questions.text: Which of the following are the goals of pre anesthetic-medication except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

GOALS OF PREMEDICATION ARE:

A)    To decrease the anxiety related to the procedure.

B)    To decrease the dose of induction agents required.

C)    To decrease the secretions.

D)    To decrease the chances of aspiration.

E)    To decrease the chances of nausea and vomiting.

F)    To facilitate smooth induction.

G)    Amnesia for the procedure

H)    Decrease in vagal tone 

I)    Prevent allergic reactions

questions.text: Most common pattern of stimulation used for monitoring neuromuscular junction is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•    There are multiple patterns of stimulation used during neuromuscular monitoring using a peripheral nerve stimulator.

•    These are single twitch, train of four, double burst stimulation and tetany

•    Of these, the most commonly used patterns are train of four (TOF).

•    In TOF stimulation 4 stimulations are given in 2 secs.

questions.text: What is the principle on which the flowmeter works:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    Flowmeter is a device on the anesthesia machine that measures the flow of carrier gases going to the patient.

•    It is comprises of a conical Pyrex glass tube called as the “ Thorpe’s tube” which has a bobbin \ float inside it that is used to measure the flow

•    Because of its tapered nature the principle of working is variable orifice and constant pressure.

questions.text: After delivering a shock, what is the next step in CPR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    Immediately after delivery of the shock , the rescuer should resume CPR without wasting time in checking for pulse and respiration.

•    After 2 mins of CPR then the rhythm is assessed again.

•    This is done to minimize the delay in chest compressions.

questions.text: Which is the fastest inhaled anesthetic agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    Speed of onset and recovery of inhaled anesthetic agent is an inverse function of its blood gas partition coefficient.

•    Among liquid volatile anesthetic agents desflurane with a blood gas partition coefficient of 0.42 is least soluble agent and so fastest onset and recovery from anesthesia

•    Slowest being methoxyflurane with a B:G coefficient of 15

questions.text: Which of the following combination is the fastest and shortest acting muscle relaxant respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    Fastest onset among muscles relaxants: scoline (30-60 secs)

•    Shortest acting muscle relaxant : scoline ( less than 10 mins)

•    Fastest onset NDMR: rocuronium ( 60-90 secs)

•    Shortest acting NDMR : mivacurium ( 15-20 mins)

choices.text: Sudden and abrupt rise of end tidal CO2 levels on capnography

questions.text: Which is the 1st manifestation of malignant hyperthermia intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Clinical manifestations of malignant hyperthermia are:

choices.text: Vital signs like respiration, heart rate

questions.text: Which of the following is used to monitor depth of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

BIS or BISpectral index is a frontal processed EEG.

► It measures the depth of anesthesia 

► The scale ranges from 0-100 and the values tell us about the depth of anesthesia

100: awake patient

80: light sedations

60: GA

40: Deep GA

20: burst suppression

0: Flat line or isoelectric eeg

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient is anesthetized for resection of a temporal lobe tumour. Preoperatively, he is lethargic and confused possibly due to raised intracranial pressure. which of the following would be the MOST appropriate drug to control systemic arterial blood pressure during direct laryngoscopy and tracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    Except propofol, all the drugs listed are potent cerebral vasodilators capable of further increasing ICP, which would be highly undesirable in this patient. 

•    Propofol is a potent cerebral vasoconstrictor that will decrease the ICP.

•    It has rapid onset of action and ultra-short duration of action.

•    Rest all the drugs won’t be very useful 

•    Ketamine: cerebral vasodilator and sympathomimetic

•    Sodium nitroprusside & Nitrous oxide: cerebral vasodilator

Drugs useful to prevent stress response to laryngoscopy and intubation are lignocaine, opioids, nitro-glycerine, calcium channel blockers such as diltiazem and β-blockers such as esmolol have been tried.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for generation of toxic by-products on long term use of inhaled anesthetic agents in closed circuit ventilation with soda lime as CO2 absorber?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    CO2 absorbers contain a combination of different agents which cause the chemical absorption of exhaled CO2.

•    Traditional co2 absorbers like soda lime and baralyme contain highly caustic substances like sodium hydroxide, potassium hydroxide or barium hydroxide.

•    These substances are highly corrosive and therefore lead to formation of toxic substances on meeting inhaled anesthetic agents.

questions.text: Which of the following pharmacologic agents would have the NO effect on somatosensory evoked potential monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Evoked potential monitoring:

•  Non-invasive assessment of neural function by measuring electro physiological responses to sensory motor pathway stimulation.

4 Types of evoked potential monitoring:

A: Somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP): most used technique

B: Visual evoked potential (VEP): most susceptible to anesthetic agents

C: Brainstem Auditory Evoked Potential (BAEP): most resistant to effect of anesthetic agents

D: Motor Evoked Potential (MEP)

•These evoked potential monitoring techniques are affected by concurrent use of anesthetic agents:

•Maximum effect is by inhaled anesthetic agent and least is by iv agents

•Muscle relaxants & nitrous oxide have no effect

questions.text: Which of the following nerve fibers are most sensitive to the action of local anesthetics?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: Automatic external defibrillator (AED) which is used for ventricular fibrillation
Automated external defibrillator (AED) which used for ventricular tachycardia
Manual defibrillator which is used for ventricular fibrillation
Automated external decompressor (AED) which is used for ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image and its correct use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

AED stands for Automated External Defibrillator

•    Public access defibrillation, which places AEDs in the hands of trained laypersons, has the potential to be the single greatest advance in the treatment of VF cardiac arrest since the development of CPR.

•    Time to defibrillation is the most important determinant of survival from cardiac arrest.

•    Survival rates after VF cardiac arrest decrease approximately 7% to 10% with every minute that defibrillation is delayed

•    The automated external defibrillator (AED) is an electronic medical device. 


•    An AED can check a person’s heart rhythm. It can recognize a rhythm that requires a shock. And it can advise the rescuer when a shock is needed. 

•    The AED uses voice prompts, lights and text messages to tell the rescuer the steps to take. 

•    AEDs are very accurate and easy to use. With training, anyone can learn to operate an AED safely.

•    Children over age 8 can be treated with a standard AED. 

•    For children ages 1–8, the AHA recommends the paediatric attenuated pads that are purchased separately. 

•    In infants < 1 years of age a manual defibrillator is preferred.

Steps of using an AED: 

Step 1: POWER ON the AED

Step 2: Attach electrode pads

•    Place the electrode pads on the upper-right sternal border (directly below the clavicle) and lateral to the left nipple, with the top margin of the pad a few inches (approximately 7 cm) below the axilla (Fig). 

•    The correct position of the electrode pads is often illustrated on the pads themselves or another part of the AED. 

•    Stop CPR just before attaching the pads. 

Step 3: Analyse the rhythm

Rhythm analysis requires from 5 to 15 seconds, depending on the brand of AED

Step 4: Clear the victim and press the SHOCK button

Before pressing the SHOCK button, ensure that no one is touching the victim. Always loudly state a “Clear the patient” message, such as “I’m clear, you’re clear, everybody clear” or simply “Clear.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not metabolised by plasma esterase:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    Metabolism of drugs used in anesthesia is of special significance.

•    Especially when we use it in context of certain organ failure patients.

•    Most drugs are metabolised by liver.

•    Certain drugs are metabolised by enzymes based in plasma.

•    Here is a list of those drugs in anesthesia

questions.text: Match the following clinical conditions with their appropriate capnography waveforms:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•    End-tidal co2 monitoring forms part of universal monitoring for anaesthesia and should also be used for all intubations and transfers in icu, emergency departments and elsewhere. 

•    Capnography measures and graphically displays co2 partial pressure over time.

•    The presence or absence of co2, the value of its partial pressure and the shape of the waveform can give valuable information for the diagnosis of many condition

•    A sloping upstroke ( SHARK FIN ) on the capnograph suggests severe asthma or copd.

•    Oesophageal intubation can be ruled out by capnography, but not an endobronchial intubation.

•    Pulmonary emboli cause v/q mismatch and reduce cardiac output, thus reducing end-tidal co2.

•    Effective cpr leads to increased co2 delivery to the lungs and hence may be monitored with capnography.

choices.text: Preparation, preoxygenation, paralysis with induction, placement of tube, positioning, postintubation management.
Preparation, preoxygenation, positioning, paralysis with induction, placement of tube, postintubation management.
Preparation, preoxygenation, paralysis with induction, placement of tube, postintubation management.
Preparation, positioning, preoxygenation, paralysis with induction, placement of tube, postintubation management

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ROUTINE AIRWAY MANAGEMENT

Routine airway management associated with general anesthesia consists of:

•    Airway assessment

•    Preparation and equipment check

•    Patient positioning

•    Preoxygenation

•    Induction agent

•    Bag and mask ventilation (BMV)

•    Muscle relaxant

•    Intubation (if indicated)

•    Confirmation of endotracheal tube placement

•    Intraoperative management and troubleshooting

•    Extubation

AIRWAY ASSESSMENT

Airway assessment is the first step in successful airway management.

Important points are: 

•    Mouth opening: an incisor distance of 3 cm or greater is desirable in an adult.

•    Mallampati classification: a frequently performed test that examines the size of the tongue in relation to the oral cavity. 

The greater the tongue obstructs the view of the pharyngeal structures, the more difficult intubation may be 

■ Class I: the entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, are visible down to their bases.

■ Class II: the upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.

■ Class III: only the soft and hard palates are visible.

■ Class IV: only the hard palate is visible.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of scoline is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mechanism of action of muscle relaxants:

1: Depolarising muscle relaxants ( DMR) : scoline : acts by partial agonism of acetylcholine receptor causing persistent depolarisation of the Ach receptor causing muscle relaxation

2: Non-Depolarising Muscle Relaxant (NDMR): competitive antagonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptor in post junctional muscle membrane

Neuromuscular transmission and sites of drug action. ( corelate with image)

(1) The action potential is conducted down the motor nerve axon and can be blocked by Na+ channel blockers, such as local anesthetics or tetrodotoxin.

(2) When the action potential reaches the nerve terminal, Ca++-mediated vesicular acetylcholine (ACh) release occurs by exocytosis, a process blocked by botulinum toxin or hemicholinium.

(3) After release, ACh diffuses across the synaptic cleft and binds to nicotinic receptors in the motor endplate. The binding can be blocked competitively by nondepolarizing neuromuscular blockers such as curare or noncompetitively by depolarizing neuromuscular blockers, such as succinylcholine.

(4) ACh is very rapidly hydrolyzed by acetylcholinesterase (AChE), which can be inhibited by cholinesterase inhibitors, such as neostigmine.

(5) ACh-activated nicotinic receptors in the motor endplate generate a muscle action potential, which leads to Ca++ release mediated by ryanodine receptors, initiating excitation-contraction coupling and muscle contraction; this Ca++ release can be blocked by the antispasticity drug dantrolene

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman undergoes total knee arthroplasty under spinal anesthesia. Two days later she complains of a severe headache. Pain intensity is related to posture. The MOST likely cause of this headache is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    PDPH is due to a loss of CSF through a Dural puncture and characteristically has a postural component.

•    When supine, the headache is usually gone but may be mild in some cases. 

•    When the head is elevated, the headache may be severe, is bilateral, and may be associated with diplopia, nausea, and vomiting.

•    The headache pain is typically frontal and/or occipital in location. 

•    Typically the onset of the headache is 12 to 24 hours after a Dural puncture and lasts several days if untreated (rarely it can last for months).

•    The other headaches listed rarely have a significant postural component

questions.text: What would be an ideal method of giving chest compressions and ventilation in a case of a 7-year-old child during an unwitnessed collapse when more than 2 rescuers are present?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Shortest acting opioid:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Remifentanil

It is a synthetic phenylpiperidine derivative of fentanyl with similar potency but is ultra-short-acting.

Pharmacokinetics

• Remifentanil is rapidly broken down by non-specific plasma and tissue esterases resulting in a short elimination half-life (3-10 minutes).

• It is context insensitive, in that the half-life, clearance and distribution are independent of duration and strength of infusion.
Effects

• Certain properties of remifentanil like rapid onset, rapid offset, organ independent metabolism and lack of accumulation make it suitable for use during various surgical procedures. However, it should be used cautiously at higher rates of infusion as serious side effects for example bradycardia, hypotension, apnoea and muscle rigidity may occur.

• Since there is no residual effect, alternative postoperative analgesic regimen should be established before infusion is terminated

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient is posted for laparoscopic appendicectomy. The child gives a history of cyanotic spells from childhood. The mother says that her child has a heart condition. Which of the following would be a preferred drug for induction of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ketamine

•    It is a phencyclidine derivative used for induction of anaesthesia

•    Pharmacodynamic effects:

•    Cardiovascular system: indirect sympathomimetic effects causing hypertension and tachycardia.

•    Respiratory system: minimum depression of breathing

•    CNS: increase in icp and cmro2

•    Uterus: uterotonic effect

•    Agent of choice in a patient with cyanotic congenital heart disease because increase in SVR ( systemic vascular resistance) decreases the right to left shunt and improves oxygenation.

questions.text:
What are the components of high-quality CPR for an adult victim?

a) Compression rate 100-120/min

b) Depth in adults 2 – 2.4 inches

c) Ventilation rate 20-25 breaths/mins

d) Allow adequate chest recoil
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

choices.text: 4 stimuli given at a gap of 0.4 seconds
Produces fade when monitoring depolarizing neuromuscular block.
Should be performed once every 5 s.

questions.text: With regards to Train Of Four stimulation for neuromuscular monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

TRAIN OF FOUR

•    Most common used pattern of stimulation

•    4 stimuli of supramaximal strength of stimuli are given over 2 seconds

•    Duration between two stimuli in a TOF is 0.5 secs

•    Frequency of stimulation is 2 hertz

•    The gap between 2 successive TOF stimulations is minimum 10 secs.

choices.text: Check Pulse, Start CPR, Call for help
Call for help, check pulse, start CPR
Go find your friend, carry patient to emergency

questions.text: You are walking in the park and see an unconscious person. What is the next step that you will take?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which oxygen delivery system is for high flow oxygen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

OXYGEN DELIVERY SYSTEMS

Oxygen delivery systems are classified as 

•    Low-flow systems: nasal prongs

•    Reservoir systems: face masks and face masks with reservoir bags

•    High flow systems: air-entrainment masks or heated, humidified O2 delivered through nasal prongs

The features of different oxygen delivery systems are summarized in Table

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents to a pain clinic with a history of back pain radiating down her right leg. She reports the pain is persistent and sometimes severe in intensity. An epidural corticosteroid injection is planned. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication of an epidural steroid injection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    An epidural corticosteroid injection is a minimally invasive procedure that can help relieve neck, arm, back, and leg pain caused by inflamed spinal nerves due to spinal stenosis or disc herniation.

•    Absolute contraindications to an epidural steroid injection include infection at the injection site, patient refusal, bleeding diathesis, and prior severe allergic reaction to injectate.

•    Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, tattoo at the injection site, and Arnold-Chiari malformation are relative contraindications.

•    The steroid is delivered to the epidural space, a fat-filled area between the bone and protective sac of the spinal nerves. Pain relief may last for several days or even years.

choices.text: Reduce the inspired inhalation concentration of isoflurane.
Stop the surgeon operating and release the muscles of the globe.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient is having retinal detachment surgery under general anaesthetic. During the surgery the patient became bradycardic with heart rate of 40 beats per minute and blood pressure of 75/40. What is the first thing would you do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    The oculo-cardiac reflex (OCR) can occur secondary to traction on the eye and ocular muscles, resulting in bradycardia. 

•    Occasionally it can cause junctional rhythm or asystole. 

•    The afferent pathway is ciliary ganglion to ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve to gasserian ganglion to main trigeminal sensory nucleus fourth ventricle. 

•    The efferent pathway is the vagus nerve. 

•    The first step in managing OCR is to release the traction on the eye. 

•    Persistent bradycardia should be treated with anticholinergic drugs. 

•    Intravenous atropine blocks the peripheral muscarinic receptors at the heart, and release of traction blocks the conduction at ciliary ganglion on the afferent limb of OCR. 

•    Atropine or glycopyrrolate can be used to treat this reflex and it can be given prophylactically. 

•    Hypoxia, hypercarbia, and light anaesthesia potentiate this reflex and should be avoided.

•    Retrobulbar block does not guarantee attenuation of this reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following landmarks are used to perform caudal epidural block?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CAUDAL EPIDURAL ANESTHESIA:

•    It is deposition of local anesthetic in caudal epidural space

•    It is meant for pediatric patients less than 8 years of age

•    Anatomical landmarks are:

•    Apex of an equilateral triangle formed by joining two posterior superior iliac spine as the base.

•    Apex coincides with sacral hiatus through which a needle is inserted in the caudal epidural space.

questions.text: An 80-year-old male with the diagnoses of coronary artery disease, hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is admitted to the intensive care unit for acute on chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure. On arrival to the emergency department, the patient was found to be acidotic. He was started on BiPAP, but his mental status deteriorated to the point where he was not responding and required intubation. Which of the following ventilation modes will be the most appropriate to use for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    In patients who have depression of their sensorium and hypercapnic respiratory depression, volume-cycled assist control ventilation is a good ventilation strategy. 

•    Assist control will ensure that the patient gets a set number of breaths even if he does not start the breath cycle on his own, which means that even if his mental status is depressed, the ventilator will make sure breaths are delivered at the set rate. 

•    Volume control means that a set tidal volume can be placed in the ventilator. This is very useful in hypercapnic respiratory failure as you can set the minute ventilation to the level required to assure correction of the hypercapnia.

•    Pressure support ventilation is a mode of ventilation in which the patient initiates the breath by inhaling, this triggers the ventilator to deliver a breath, which is then supported by a set amount of pressure programmed on the ventilator. 

•    In a patient with decreased mental status who might not have spontaneous breathing, this is not an ideal mode of ventilation.

•    HFOV is a mode of ventilation where a mean airway pressure is selected, and the ventilator will deliver very quick oscillations in pressure above and below the pressure. 

•    This generates small and fast tidal volumes. 

•    This mode of ventilation will not be ideal to manage hypercapnic respiratory failure as it is harder to adjust for the desired minute ventilation.

•    APRV is a mode of ventilation in which a constant high pressure is delivered to the lung to improve oxygenation, and ventilation is managed by the release of that pressure. 

•    APRV may give unreliable tidal volumes. 

•    It is used for hypoxic respiratory failure with great success in difficult to oxygenate patients that fail other ventilator methods. 

•    For this patient with hypercapnic respiratory failure, AC is a better method.

questions.text: After placement of an epidural catheter in a 55-year-old patient for total hip arthroplasty, an entire epidural dose is administered into the subarachnoid space. Physiologic effects consistent with subarachnoid injection of large volumes of local anesthetic include all the following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    With the unintentional injection of an epidural dose of local anesthetic into the subarachnoid space, spinal anesthesia develops rapidly. (TOTAL SPINAL)

•    Blockade of the sympathetic fibres (T1-L2) produces hypotension, particularly if the patient is hypovolemic. 

•    Bradycardia is produced by blocking the cardiac accelerator fibres (T1-T4). 

•    Respiratory arrest is due to hypoperfusion of the respiratory centres as well as paralysis of the phrenic nerve (C3-C5). 

•    Convulsions are a part of local anesthetic systemic toxicity when a large volume of local is injected in intravascular space.

•    If one suspects an unintentional placement of the epidural dose subarachnoid, supportive methods are initially used (the basic ABC’s of resuscitation).

•    One can also aspirate CSF from the epidural catheter (if it was inserted) to help remove some of the drug as well as reducing the pressure in the subarachnoid space, which might help better perfuse the spinal cord and decrease the chance of cauda equina syndrome developing

choices.text: It acts by inhibiting the reuptake of noradrenergic and serotonergic system

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of tramadol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•    Tramadol is phenylpiperidine analogue of codeine. 

•    It is weak agonist at all opioid receptors with 20-fold preference for MOP receptors. 

•    It inhibits neuronal reuptake of norepinephrine. 

•    It potentiates release of serotonin and causes descending inhibition of nociception.

questions.text: Which of the following is a variable oxygen delivery device except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    A variable oxygen delivery device is the one where the oxygen delivery is dependant on the efforts of the patient. Eg : hudson’s face mask, nasal cannulae

•    A fixed oxygen delivery device is the one where the FIO2 delivered is irrespective of the breathing efforts of the patient eg : venturi mask, face mask with a reservoir bag
